items.title: Unable to parse editable (-e) requirement
items.body:
`[WARNING] Skipping u'-e vendor/XXX': could not parse requirement`

Is this expected, as in does `caniusepython3` do recursive checks for example for `-r base.txt`?

items.title: Unable to parse requirement file using git tag
items.body:
```
[WARNING] Skipping u'git+https://github.com/auzigog/jinja-bootstrap.git@v0.4.0': could not parse requirement
```

items.title: Add optional argument for enabling structured output
items.body:
Add optional argument for enabling structured output.

Enabling structured output to formats such as json would make parsing the output for use in CI's or other scripts simpler.

I imagine this would be an argument such as `--json` or `--format default` & `--format json`.

Default output would remain the same, and formatted output might look like:
```
{
    'supported': ['p3_compatible1', 'p3_compatible2', ...],
    'unsupported': ['p3_incompatible1', 'p3_incompatible2', ...],
    'errors': {'404': ['unknown1', 'unknown2', ...], ...} 
}
```

items.title: Package available on pypi.org but not on https://www.red-dove.com/pypi
items.body:
(This is probably not an issue with `caniusepython3`, but I thought it would be helpful to document how to deal with it.)

`caniusepython3` complains (see below) about `fbprophet`, despite this package being [available](https://pypi.org/project/fbprophet/) on pypi.org.

This is because it's not available at <https://www.red-dove.com/pypi/projects/F/fbprophet/>, as expected by `caniusepython3`.

Is this a known issue with pypi? Is there anything a user can do to fix this? Or should a user just add an override for this package?

```
$ caniusepython3 --projects fbprophet
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[ERROR] Failed to get external data for https://www.red-dove.com/pypi/projects/F/fbprophet/project.json: HTTP Error 404: Not Found
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/francis/.local/pipx/venvs/caniusepython3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/distlib/util.py", line 909, in _get_external_data
    resp = urlopen(url)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 222, in urlopen
    return opener.open(url, data, timeout)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 531, in open
    response = meth(req, response)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 641, in http_response
    'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 569, in error
    return self._call_chain(*args)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 503, in _call_chain
    result = func(*args)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/urllib/request.py", line 649, in http_error_default
    raise HTTPError(req.full_url, code, msg, hdrs, fp)
urllib.error.HTTPError: HTTP Error 404: Not Found
[WARNING] fbprophet not found
```

items.title: no development instructions
items.body:
This is a bit more minor, but I wasn't able to figure out how to test out the command locally, and wasn't able to find any documentation as such. For instance:

```
$ python caniusepython3/__main__.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 18, in <module>
    from caniusepython3 import dependencies
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'caniusepython3'
```

The same error occurs if I try to symlink this file from the project root.

However, a hack that did work was copying `caniusepython3/__main__.py` to say `ciup3.py`, installing some requirements into a venv (eg. `distlib`, `packaging`, `requests`), and then running `python ciup3.py ...` from the project root. Of course, this does mean that if one wants to cut a release, the modified `ciup3.py` would have to be copied back to the original location.

There might be a more proper way that is preferred over this?

items.title: no support for versioned requirements
items.body:
Case in point:
```
$ python ciup3.py -p supervisor
Finding and checking dependencies ...
{'supervisor'}

🎉  You have 0 projects blocking you from using Python 3!

$ python ciup3.py -p supervisor==3.3.1
Finding and checking dependencies ...
{'supervisor==3-3-1'}
[WARNING] problem fetching supervisor==3-3-1, assuming ported (404)

🎉  You have 0 projects blocking you from using Python 3!
```

This is expected based on current behaviour, since https://pypi.org/pypi/supervisor/json shows the 3.7 trove classifier. But it is missing in an older version: https://pypi.org/pypi/supervisor/3.3.1/json

Because of this, projects could be depending on older versions of dependencies that lack py3 support, even though the newest versions do have py3 support, and thus things could get missed at various points in the dependency graph.

Due to the way this system is designed (after an initial inspection of the source), it looks like supporting this might be a somewhat nontrivial enhancement. But, would welcome expert opinion on how feasible this might be?

items.title: Add Python 3.7 to classifiers and remove Python 3.4/add Python 3.7 from tox
items.body:
Although this project is currently testing under Python 3.7 and even 3.8-dev and tests are green, the Python 3.7 Trove classifier is not present in ``setup.py``. Furthermore, a ``py34`` env is still listed in ``tox.ini``, while ``py37`` is not. Just want to make sure this project is classified correctly itself, heh; per your [Contributing Guidelines](https://github.com/brettcannon/caniusepython3/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) :

> ## Supporting a new release of Python
>
> Make sure to update both the `.travis.yml` and `tox.ini` files to list the new version.

items.title: Add support for excluding non-py3 compliant packages which helps for legacy projects
items.body:
Some legacy python projects which are in the process of porting, can benefit from having a exclude argument which lists the py3 incompatible packages they have as their current dependencies,  they want to skip the check. 

This way they make sure new packages added to the requirements are all py3 compatible, while they work on a plan to figure out how to port/decommision py3 non-compliant current packages.

items.title: Add support for precommit
items.body: Would be great if we can use this tool as a pre-commit hook.

items.title: PyHive not detected as python 3 compatible
items.body: The PyHive library is compatible with Python 3. From https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive#requirements, "PyHive works Python 2.7 / Python 3" but it is flagged as non-compatible.

items.title: slumber not detected as Python 3 compatible
items.body:
The [slumber](https://pypi.org/project/slumber/) library is compatible with Python 3, and its [setup.py](https://github.com/samgiles/slumber/blob/master/setup.py#L50) includes the Python 3.4 trove classifier. It is, however, flagged as not compatible:

```
$ caniusepython3 --projects slumber
Finding and checking dependencies ...

You need 1 project to transition to Python 3.
Of that 1 project, 1 has no direct dependencies blocking its transition:

  slumber
```

items.title: No Support for Using Different Indexes
items.body: For those who have internal indexes and internal packages, there is a gap because this script will 404 on packages not in pypi. Might be nice if it parsed out `index-url` from requirements or had a command line option to pass in a different index.

items.title: Wrong check result for python-oauth2
items.body:
Calling `caniusepython3 --projects python-oauth2` shows a negative result for Python 3 compatibility.

The PyPI page for the project: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-oauth2

The package works fine with Python 3.4 in my project, their setup.py file also has an according language indication. There might be a syntax error in the classifier list, since the PyPI home page also does not show the classifiers, but I failed to find it.

items.title: biopython and numexpr wrongfully listed as needing transition
items.body: In fact both work on Python 3.

items.title: Release new version and fix changelog
items.body: The changelog for v4.0.0 (https://github.com/brettcannon/caniusepython3#400) says `Return a 3 error code when a command completes successfully but there are found blockers (patch by pcattori)` but the commit for that update isn't included in the v4.0.0 version.  Can you create release another version of caniusepython3 that includes that patch?

items.title: Specify requires_python in setup.py
items.body: Supported in pip 9 and the latest version of setuptools: https://mail.python.org/pipermail/distutils-sig/2016-November/029785.html. Will need something like `">=2.7,!=3.0*,!=3.1*,!=3.2*"` to match our "2.7 or 3.3 and higher" requirement.

items.title: caniusepython3 doesn't check python3 compatibility with packages versions
items.body:
e.g. if you have a package "Django==1.4.22" in your requirements.txt, it will get flagged as python3 compatible because later versions of django support python3.

It would be better if caniusepython3 checked the specific package version, and then returned the minimum version required to upgrade to python3.

Excuse me if this is already a feature, but it doesn't seem obvious from the documentation

items.title: `ImportError: No module named backports.functools_lru_cache`
items.body:
When installing directly from github `pip install -e git+https://github.com/brettcannon/caniusepython3#egg=caniusepython3` and running `python setup.py caniusepython3` on python 2.7.12 you get the error above.

Seems that #156 makes use of `backports.functools_lru_cache` but that package is not installed as part of the dependencies. Should probably be added to the `install_requires` section of `setup.py` before the latest version gets published to PyPI :)

items.title: exit codes for `python setup.py caniusepython3`
items.body: would be nice if this exited with an non-zero exit code ~~of `1`~~ when a dependency was not python 3 compatible. that way tools like Travis could simply run `python setup.py caniusepython3` and rely on the exit code to determine whether it passed or failed

items.title: blocking dependencies not found if dependent says it supports Python 3
items.body:
Two examples:
- `caniusepython3 --projects dd` says that `dd` is ready, because `dd` says so in [its Trove classifiers](https://github.com/johnyf/dd/blob/8113aa95563df13cd2c66f22ccf3aba32dd2b465/setup.py#L45). However, `dd` [depends on](https://github.com/johnyf/dd/blob/8113aa95563df13cd2c66f22ccf3aba32dd2b465/setup.py#L27) `astutils`, which [has forgotten](https://github.com/johnyf/astutils/blob/075e84f6d32e212edc54b80c38163956c6d4b600/setup.py) (me) to declare so with any classifiers. I would expect `caniusepython3` to traverse the entire dependency graph in search for any dependency that cannot be confirmed to be compatible with Python 3. The current behavior seems to truncate the search or the report at the first ancestors that themselves have no Python 3 incompatible ancestors. In this particular case, the truncation happens at the named package, `dd`.
- `caniusepython3 --projects omega` says that `omega` is the only project that needs to transition to Python 3. However, `omega` [depends on `dd`](https://github.com/johnyf/omega/blob/5c1a364b9a596973150f488ecb386d8fda3f2546/setup.py#L24), which depends on `astutils`, which does not declare it is compatible with Python 3. So, the report truncates at `dd`, as above, and `astutils` remains hidden behind it.

For completeness, `caniusepython3 --projects astutils` reports `astutils` to be blocking to itself.

In principle, that a package declares compatibility with Python 3 should be considered as a promise by the package that it has ensured its dependencies work in Python 3 too. But, it doesn't mean that the package has ensured that all its dependencies (ancestors included) are correctly declaring their compatibility with Python 3 using Trove classifiers.

Also, it would be helpful to report the intermediate packages found (i.e., not only those with no Python 3-incompatible ancestors). A package relevant to that purpose is [`pipdeptree`](https://github.com/naiquevin/pipdeptree).

items.title: nonexistent dependency reported due to erroneous red-dove data used by `distlib`
items.body:
`caniusepython3 --projects omega` reports [`yaclifw`](https://github.com/openmicroscopy/yaclifw) as a dependency of [`omega`](https://github.com/johnyf/omega), but it is not.

The error is due to `distlib` fetching erroneous data from red-dove.com, and has been reported here:
https://bitbucket.org/pypa/distlib/issues/86/red-dove-metadata-misnaming-error
A temporary fix is: https://github.com/johnyf/distlib/commit/597290ddfcb7064051e62a50142ab412122c0d14
In `caniusepython3`, the error originates in [`caniusepython3.dependencies.dependencies`](https://github.com/brettcannon/caniusepython3/blob/0d025e23c5ee25dd26111f26495858b5aa133236/caniusepython3/dependencies.py#L58). A full call trace can be found in the `distlib` issue mentioned above.

The simplest way that I can think of to avoid this situation here is to either:
- instantiate `AggregatingLocator(
                  SimpleScrapingLocator('https://pypi.python.org/simple/',
                                        timeout=3.0),
                  scheme='legacy')` (i.e., omit `JSONLocator`, compared to what `distlib` does), or
- instantiate directly a [`SimpleScrapingLocator`](https://github.com/vsajip/distlib/blob/1d806f5ad38d04c292dd0895016f6f24f9932ca5/distlib/locators.py#L571),

and then call the method `SimpleScrapingLocator.locate` in `caniusepython3.dependencies.dependencies`.

This issue appears thematically in the same area with #126, but it appears to be a different problem.

items.title: ProtocolError when calling all_py3_projects
items.body:
pypi.org appears to be pointing to warehouse today, causing calls to `pypi.all_py3_projects()` to throw:

```
ProtocolError: <ProtocolError for pypi.io/pypi: 301 Redirect to Primary Domain>
```

Time to speed up #148?

items.title: Find a better way to look up whether a project supports Python 3
items.body: Currently the XML-RPC API's `browse()` function is used, but the XML-RPC library is hard on pypi.python.org and not necessarily the fastest thing. I have opened https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/1393 to see if it's possible to have Warehouse provide a caching replacement. If not, though, it's probably better to just check individual projects rather than the overarching request for all Python 3 projects.

items.title: Use pypi.org/simple to get the list of all PyPI projects
items.body: For use in `pypi.all_projects()`.

items.title: New PyPI release needed
items.body:
It looks like the release currently on PyPI fails due to a change in the allowed protocols for API access to PyPI:

```
Finding and checking dependencies ...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/jeremybowman/.virtualenvs/bok-choy/bin/caniusepython3", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/Users/jeremybowman/.virtualenvs/bok-choy/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 179, in main
    check(projects_from_cli(args))
  File "/Users/jeremybowman/.virtualenvs/bok-choy/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 167, in check
    blockers = dependencies.blocking_dependencies(projects, pypi.all_py3_projects())
  File "/Users/jeremybowman/.virtualenvs/bok-choy/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/pypi.py", line 112, in all_py3_projects
    for result in map(projects_matching_classifier, py3_classifiers()):
  File "/Users/jeremybowman/.virtualenvs/bok-choy/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/pypi.py", line 98, in projects_matching_classifier
    for result in client.browse([classifier]))
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/xmlrpclib.py", line 1240, in __call__
    return self.__send(self.__name, args)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/xmlrpclib.py", line 1599, in __request
    verbose=self.__verbose
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/xmlrpclib.py", line 1280, in request
    return self.single_request(host, handler, request_body, verbose)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.11/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/xmlrpclib.py", line 1328, in single_request
    response.msg,
xmlrpclib.ProtocolError: <ProtocolError for pypi.python.org/pypi: 403 Must access using HTTPS instead of HTTP>
```

Current master works, as it changed to use HTTPS (and uses a different server).

items.title: Use pypi.io for Trove classifiers
items.body: https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/1241

items.title: Give an explanation of what a "stale override" is in logging message
items.body: Brought up in #131 by @edmorley

items.title: Make tests more robust
items.body: I.e. if a 5XX return code is raised like https://travis-ci.org/brettcannon/caniusepython3/jobs/135734656 then simply skip the test.

items.title: Dynamically download overrides.json if possible
items.body: If it can be downloaded w/o timeout or error code from GitHub, then try and fetch the GitHub version as it's the most up-to-date. In cases of failure, fall back on the included copy.

items.title: Dependency reported as not compatible with Python 3 is reported compatible when checked directly
items.body:
### Versions

caniusepython3: 3.3.0
Python: 2.7.11
### Actual Output

```
$ caniusepython3 -p cmsplugin-filer
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[WARNING] Stale overrides: set([u'reportlab', u'extras', u'pyvirtualdisplay'])

You need 2 projects to transition to Python 3.
Of those 2 projects, 1 has no direct dependencies blocking its transition:

  easy_thumbnails (which is blocking cmsplugin-filer)
```

Ok, so there's one dependency that blocks `cmsplugin-filer`. When I saw that, I went to pypi page for `easy-thumbnails` and saw there that it supports Python 3. Let's see what happens if I run a check directly on it:

```
$ caniusepython3 -p easy-thumbnails
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[WARNING] Stale overrides: set([u'reportlab', u'extras', u'pyvirtualdisplay'])

🎉  You have 0 projects blocking you from using Python 3!
```

Using an underscore for the dash makes no difference:

```
$ caniusepython3 -p easy_thumbnails
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[WARNING] Stale overrides: set([u'reportlab', u'extras', u'pyvirtualdisplay'])

🎉  You have 0 projects blocking you from using Python 3!
```
### Expected Output

I would expect that `easy-thumbnails` would not block `cmsplugin-filer` since it supports Python 3.

But the package that is searched for is sphinx-py3doc-enhanced-theme

items.title: Stop using Tox with Travis
items.body: Relying on the default Python container from Travis to expose all Python binaries doesn't work thanks to Python 3.5 missing: https://travis-ci.org/brettcannon/caniusepython3/jobs/115378739. That means Tox use should be dropped from `.travis.yml` and a more traditional Travis setup: https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/languages/python.

items.title: numpy already supports Python 3
items.body:
Numpy already supports Python3. And this CLI was working fine. Recently, something has changed and it gives following output.

```
$ caniusepython3 --projects numpy
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[WARNING] Stale overrides: set([u'reportlab'])

You need 1 project to transition to Python 3.
Of that 1 project, 1 has no direct dependencies blocking its transition:

  numpy
```

Not sure if it is the case with packages that specify version number in PyPi like https://pypi.python.org/pypi/numpy/ gives 404 so we have to use https://pypi.python.org/pypi/numpy/1.8.1

This issue was fist reported here https://github.com/chhantyal/py3readiness/issues/24

items.title: Make tests less flaky in the face of PyPI timing out

items.title: Consider switching to Fastly copy of metadata
items.body: See https://github.com/jezdez/caniusepython3.com/blob/master/ciupy3/__init__.py on how to do it.

items.title: pylint_checker doesn't handle from __future__ import unicode_literals
items.body:
Sample file:

```
"""Module Docstring"""
from __future__ import absolute_import
from __future__ import division
from __future__ import print_function
from __future__ import unicode_literals

def awesome():
    print("awesome")
```

Running `pylint --load-plugins=caniusepython3.pylint_checker --py3k sample.py --report=no` yields the following:

```
************* Module t5
W:  7, 0: native string literal (native-string)
```

items.title: Override ipaddress
items.body: It's a backport of the builtin python3 module, so probably could be ignored in some way?

```
  File "$HOME/.local/venvs/caniusepython3/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 167, in check

  File "$HOME/.local/venvs/caniusepython3/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/dependencies.py", line 81, in blocking_dependencies
    dist = distlib.locators.locate(project)
  File "$HOME/.local/venvs/caniusepython3/lib/python2.7/site-packages/distlib/locators.py", line 361, in locate
    result.download_urls = versions.get('urls', {}).get(version, set())
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'download_urls'
```

items.title: Drop Python 2.6 support
items.body: It's 7 years old, so it's past security fixes and just plain old buggy compared to Python 2.7.

Found when checking kotti_tinymce:

items.title: TypeError thrown when looking at all pypi projects.
items.body:
While running a very simple but long running program I received this stack.

Program Code:

```
from collections import Counter
from pprint import pprint

import caniusepython3
from caniusepython3.dependencies import blocking_dependencies

all_py_projects = list(caniusepython3.pypi.all_projects())
py3_projects = caniusepython3.pypi.all_py3_projects()
all_blockers = blocking_dependencies(
    all_py_projects,
    py3_projects)
blocker_list = []
for blockers_subset in all_blockers:
    for blocker in blockers_subset:
        blocker_list.append(blocker)
blockers_counter = Counter(blocker_list)
pprint(blockers_counter.most_common())
```

Just as a warning this takes my poor laptop a couple hours to run.

Stack

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "top_python3_blockers.py", line 15, in <module>
    py3_projects)
  File "/Users/alexlord/.virtualenvs/porting_authority/lib/python3.4/site-packages/caniusepython3-3.1.0-py3.4.egg/caniusepython3/dependencies.py", line 98, in blocking_dependencies
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.2_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 549, in result_iterator
    yield future.result()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.2_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 395, in result
    return self.__get_result()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.2_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 354, in __get_result
    raise self._exception
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.2_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/concurrent/futures/thread.py", line 54, in run
    result = self.fn(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
  File "/Users/alexlord/.virtualenvs/porting_authority/lib/python3.4/site-packages/caniusepython3-3.1.0-py3.4.egg/caniusepython3/dependencies.py", line 60, in dependencies
  File "/Users/alexlord/.virtualenvs/porting_authority/lib/python3.4/site-packages/distlib/database.py", line 375, in run_requires
    return self._get_requirements('run_requires')
  File "/Users/alexlord/.virtualenvs/porting_authority/lib/python3.4/site-packages/distlib/database.py", line 371, in _get_requirements
    env=self.context))
  File "/Users/alexlord/.virtualenvs/porting_authority/lib/python3.4/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 874, in get_requirements
    result.extend(d['requires'])
TypeError: string indices must be integers
```

I'm going to re-run the sample code using `python  -m pdb` to see if I can figure out what's happening.

items.title: Outputs `No handlers could be found for logger "ciu"`
items.body:
Note `No handlers could be found for logger "ciu"` in the output below. I haven't yet looked into why it's showing up, but it would be nice if it didn't.

```
$ python setup.py caniusepython3
running caniusepython3
Finding and checking dependencies ...
No handlers could be found for logger "ciu"

You need 3 projects to transition to Python 3.
Of those 3 projects, 2 have no direct dependencies blocking their transition:

  gevent
  paste (which is blocking pastescript)
```

items.title: Error when using distlib==0.2.0
items.body:
So I'm not sure where the bug is, but I ran into this bug when running caniusepython3:

```
kevin@myserver:~$ /usr/local/bin/caniusepython3 -r requirements.txt
Finding and checking dependencies ...
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/caniusepython3", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 159, in main
    check(projects_from_cli(args))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 145, in check
    blockers = dependencies.blocking_dependencies(projects, pypi.all_py3_projects())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/dependencies.py", line 80, in blocking_dependencies
    dist = distlib.locators.locate(project)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/distlib/locators.py", line 361, in locate
    result.download_urls = versions.get('urls', {}).get(version, set())
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'download_urls'
```

I fixed it by rolling back to distlib==0.1.9, though that gave me these errors

```
Finding and checking dependencies ...
[WARNING] recaptcha not found  
[WARNING] django-recaptcha-field not found
[ERROR] Failed to get external data for https://www.red-dove.com/pypi/projects/E/email-reply-parser/project.json: HTTP Error 404: Not Found
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/distlib/util.py", line 744, in _get_external_data
    resp = urlopen(url)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 126, in urlopen
    return _opener.open(url, data, timeout)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 406, in open
    response = meth(req, response)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 519, in http_response
    'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 444, in error
    return self._call_chain(*args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 378, in _call_chain
    result = func(*args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 527, in http_error_default
    raise HTTPError(req.get_full_url(), code, msg, hdrs, fp)
HTTPError: HTTP Error 404: Not Found

You need 17 projects to transition to Python 3.
Of those 17 projects, 15 have no direct dependencies blocking their transition:

  django-celery-transactions   
  django-concurrent-server
  django-discover-jenkins
  django-include-strip-tag
  django-ipware
  django-storages
  docx
  hellosign-python-sdk
  oauth2
  pdfminer
  pykss
  reportlab
  lepl (which is blocking rfc6266)
  m2crypto (which is blocking tender_multipass)
  xlsxcessive
```

Not sure if this is a problem with distlib, my setup, or maybe freezing the required version of distlib in the requirements. Happy to report more as necessary. If it helps, I'm running python 2.7.3 in ubuntu 12.04

items.title: TypeError: 'int' object is not iterable
items.body:
I ran `caniusepython3 -r requirements.txt` against [my requirements.txt](https://github.com/technoskald/maltrieve/blob/master/requirements.txt) and the following error resulted:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/caniusepython3", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 159, in main
    check(projects_from_cli(args))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 86, in projects_from_cli
    projects.extend(projects_from_requirements(parsed.requirements))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 39, in projects_from_requirements
    for req in reqs:
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 1631, in parse_requirements
    req = InstallRequirement.from_line(line, comes_from, prereleases=getattr(options, "pre", None))
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 172, in from_line
    return cls(req, comes_from, url=url, prereleases=prereleases)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 108, in __init__
    self.prereleases = any([is_prerelease(x[1]) and x[0] != "!=" for x in self.req.specs])
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/util.py", line 720, in is_prerelease
    return any([any([y in set(["a", "b", "c", "rc", "dev"]) for y in x]) for x in parsed])
TypeError: 'int' object is not iterable
```

For context, this is on Python 2.7.6 on Ubuntu 14.04.

items.title: TypeError: parse_requirements() missing 1 required keyword argument: 'session'

Hello!

`caniusepython3==2.2.0` and `pip 6.0.6`

items.title: [feature] an option to suggest close/drop-in alternative
items.body:
There is this package called `oauth2` which seems to be very popular. Unfortunately it's abandoned and has no activity since 2011 https://github.com/simplegeo/python-oauth2

There are nice alternative packages like this one https://github.com/idan/oauthlib, which are actively developed, as well as popular. Can we somehow add a feature to let people that there is close/drop-in alternative which supports Python 3? 

In above example, `oauth2` should not be holding people back. What do you think?

items.title: What about non-existent projects?
items.body:
Currently you can search for any project and caniusepython3 will report it's Python3 compatible... If you press on "Check again" in the result page will 404 you.
![caiusepy3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1037088/3336041/f75147ca-f821-11e3-8457-ada431a80cf3.png)

items.title: Add overrides for pyephem
items.body:
Unfortunately [`pyephem`](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pyephem) uses the different name  [`ephem`](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ephem/) on Python 3. Otherwise it is the exact same project (`import ephem`). See [Python3 Version issue](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/issues/23).

To confuse matters further, [`pyephem` now has Python 3 classifiers](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/commit/40572e34cbe83d9618966e600bdc0e0d880d07bf)

items.title: Package name normalization is not handled correctly
items.body:
For example:

```
$ caniusepython3 --projects wsgi_intercept
Finding and checking dependencies ...
No handlers could be found for logger "ciu"

You have 0 projects blocking you from using Python 3!

$ caniusepython3 --projects wsgi-intercept
Finding and checking dependencies ...
No handlers could be found for logger "ciu"

You need 1 project to transition to Python 3.
Of that 1 project, 1 has no direct dependencies blocking its transition:

  wsgi-intercept
```

items.title: pyramid_mako (among others) is not recognized as py3 compatible
items.body:
Seems some packages are not correctly recognized even though they have the required classifiers on PyPI.

For example `pyramid_mako`.

One thing I noticed is that on the website entering `pyramid_mako` turns out as `pyramid-mako` (underscore converted to dash). Maybe it does not find that on PyPI...?

BR

items.title: Fix logging format
items.body: https://bitbucket.org/pypa/distlib/issue/46/logging-messages-not-being-formatted

items.title: Marking packages which have alternatives as supporting Python3 is very confusing
items.body:
I just spent 10 minutes trying to understand how python-memcached supports python3, before I realized there's actually a fork which does.

It seems to be there should be some sort of alternate presentation of this info.

items.title: Use unittest2
items.body: Now it just seems silly to be working around it not being installed in the tests if I'm going to pull in mock as well.

items.title: Import caniusepython3.pypi directly
items.body: Now necessary from command and dependency thanks to just_name(); otherwise might need to move the function to **init**.

items.title: Add tests to cover just_name() rename failure
items.body: e3dd493e1fcf234fd80f63b323d4f884190175c8 should not have been needed. Figure out where the hole in the testing is and plug it.

items.title: Push Git tags to Github
items.body: I was just trying to find out whether there are API incompatibilities between 1.2.1 and 2.x as I'm using some of it in caniusepython3.com. Sadly I couldn't find the Git tags for the project. Mind if you push them?

items.title: Unknown projects should be considered ported
items.body: If someone uses caniusepython3 with some dependencies that are private to their project, we have no way of knowing they are ported, so instead of erroneously saying that they can never switch, but the onus on them and say they can until they move their own private dependencies over.

items.title: Use an environment variable to signify changing the name of the command
items.body: To use the `icanhazpython3` hack, you need to edit `setup.py`, but that doesn't work if you use pip. Probably better to let people set an environment variable like `CIU_ICANHAZPYTHON3` to a true value to flag they want the alternative name used during installation.

items.title: Add a change log
items.body: With the imminent release of version 2.0 it's time to start keeping a change log for major changes that will affect users. Unfortunately with GitHub using Markdown and PyPI using reST, it's already annoying to maintain two files. My current thinking is to make PyPI host the docs for the use of caniusepython3 and then have `README.md` host the change log and any other development details.

items.title: Expose API for testing for Python 3 compatibility
items.body: Could allow projects to make a simple call in their unit tests that starts failing when all of their dependencies have been ported.

items.title: Make passing in overrides data as optional
items.body: For  jezdez/caniusepython3.com#3

items.title: Add a test for -v
items.body: 0c146de6c65bb5a28a4bbd1f099553633ac32ca9 should never have happened. Shouldn't need to be anything more than verifying that 'INFO' is found in the output.

items.title: Misidentified projects: boto, botocore, jinja2
items.body:
I would submit a patch for this, but I'm not sure what the problem is.

`boto`, `botocore`, and `jinja2` all explicitly support Python 3, but `caniusepython3` claims they don't. It doesn't seem appropriate to add them to the overrides because they do have some form of `Programming Language :: Python :: 3` classifier.

items.title: Override pil with pillow
Mention caniusepython3.com in the docs?
items.body: I hope that is okay with you, I thought it would help spread the word a bit.

items.title: What should we do with deprecated packages?
items.body: For eg, https://github.com/omab/django-social-auth is deprecated in favor of python-social-auth. I see it is not overridden. Any plan to do something about them as those packages will never Python 3 support?

items.title: Ignore/warn for local packages in requirements.txt
items.body:
File paths listed in a requirements.txt return a None at some point and cause an AttributeError later on.

Traceback:

```
$ caniusepython3 -r requirements.txt
Finding and checking dependencies ...
WARNING:root:Stale overrides: set([u'pyopenssl'])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/caniusepython3", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/__main__.py", line 119, in main
    blockers = ciu.blocking_dependencies(projects, ciu.all_py3_projects())
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/caniusepython3/__init__.py", line 169, in blocking_dependencies
    for project in projects if project.lower() not in py3_projects]
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lower'
```

items.title: Add test for not using editable deps from a requirements.txt file
items.body: Semantics added in 7c27dfb6ff6a0e69577005a2ffcc7bb0954f44b0 from @jezdez.

items.title: Add HTTPretty to overrides.json
items.body: https://twitter.com/CyrilRoelandt/status/437995014321238016

items.title: File bugs against projects missing trove classifier in overrides.json
items.body:
- [x] ~~mox3~~ (can't find source repo)
- [x] [pbr](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbr) ([code](https://github.com/openstack-dev/pbr), [pull request](https://github.com/openstack-dev/pbr/pull/6) which will get ignored, [pull request by @Steap](https://review.openstack.org/#/c/74543/))
- [x] [pylint](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pylint) ([code](https://bitbucket.org/logilab/pylint/), [bug](https://bitbucket.org/logilab/pylint/issue/152/provide-trove-classifiers-in-setuppy))
- [x] [pyopenssl](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pyopenssl) ([code](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl), [pull request](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl/pull/45); also already updated with 2.x classifiers)
- [x] [python-novaclient](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-novaclient) ([code](https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient), [bug](https://review.openstack.org/#/c/75964/))
- [x] [rsa](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/rsa) ([code](https://bitbucket.org/sybren/python-rsa), [pull request](https://bitbucket.org/sybren/python-rsa/pull-request/8/list-python-3-support-in-setuppy/diff))
- [x] [zc.recipe.egg](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/zc.recipe.egg) ([code](https://github.com/buildout/buildout/tree/master/zc.recipe.egg_), [pull request](https://github.com/buildout/buildout/pull/168))

items.title: Accept a setup.py file as an argument
items.body: Should be able to add a `-s`/`--setup` argument which takes a path to a `setup.py` file and then executes it to tease out the dependencies.

items.title: Require user specify *some* argument that leads to specifying projects
items.body: Not specifying anything isn't an error right now but leads to pointless output.

items.title: Dynamically fetch valid Python 3 trove classifiers
items.body: The guarding code for detecting new releases of Python is somewhat silly when the entire list of trove classifiers can be fetched and then searched to find all valid Python 3 classifiers.

items.title: Break out overrides data into own JSON file
items.body: Will require making the project a package (which wouldn't be so bad). Can keep it zip_safe by using `pkgutil.get_data()` to read the JSON file out of the zip file.

items.title: PyPI
items.body: Can this be on PyPI?

items.title: Fix requirements.txt parsing
items.body:
Currently the `pkg_resources.parse_requirements` function is used. Sadly this isn't the correct way to parse _pip_ requirements files (since it's a non-standard, just like pkg_resources).

Either use pip's own functionality (https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/develop/pip/req/req_file.py#L12) or a 3rd party app like https://github.com/davidfischer/requirements-parser (which probably only implements half of it though)

items.title: Look into making this a Python2/3 compatible package
items.body: I think this would go a long way to help switchers to check their Python 2 based projects whether they're ready. Only providing a Python 3 compatible version seems like a bottleneck that can easily be prevented.

items.title: Add support for installing this as a wheel
Consider making caniusepython3 a script
items.body:
I.e. don't use `py_modules` in setup.py but instead use `scripts` and then simply rename `caniusepython3.py` to `caniusepython3`. Since it is fully self-contained and there is no API beyond the CLI the only thing that would be an issue is the tests, but those could even be integrated into the single file.

Otherwise look into using [Setuptools' automatic script creation](http://pythonhosted.org/setuptools/setuptools.html#automatic-script-creation).

items.title: Parallelize fetching of projects
items.body: While the total set of project is unknown and thus can't necessarily make everything concurrent, at least making the fetching of direct dependencies concurrent would be helpful.
